bcl:text.#text: section 11 , or

bcl:text.#text: means a request under section 4 ;

means a claim over which the tribunal has jurisdiction under Division 6  of Part 10;

means

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the chair,

bcl:text.#text: a vice chair or other tribunal member appointed under section 68 , or
a temporary tribunal member appointed under section 69 ;

means a claim over which the tribunal has jurisdiction under Division 3  of Part 10, but does not include any other claim category;

means a person appointed as a vice chair of the tribunal under section 68 (1) .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A claim that may be either a tribunal small claim or a claim in another claim category within the jurisdiction of the tribunal is to be adjudicated as the claim category that is not a tribunal small claim.

For the purposes of this Act, the tribunal has exclusive jurisdiction in respect of a claim if the claim is in a claim category in respect of which the applicable Division of Part 10 provides that the tribunal has exclusive jurisdiction.

For the purposes of this Act, the tribunal is to be considered to have specialized expertise in respect of a claim if the claim is in a claim category in respect of which the applicable Division of Part 10 provides that the tribunal is to be considered to have specialized expertise.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Civil Resolution Tribunal mandate and role

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The Civil Resolution Tribunal is established, consisting of the chair and other tribunal members appointed in accordance with this Act.
The mandate of the tribunal is to provide dispute resolution services in relation to matters that are within its authority, in a manner that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is accessible, speedy, economical, informal and flexible,
applies principles of law and fairness, and recognizes any relationships between parties to a dispute that will likely continue after the tribunal proceeding is concluded,
uses electronic communication tools to facilitate resolution of disputes brought to the tribunal, and
accommodates, so far as the tribunal considers reasonably practicable, the diversity of circumstances of the persons using the services of the tribunal.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In fulfilling its mandate, the role of the tribunal is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to encourage the resolution of disputes by agreement between the parties, and
if resolution by agreement is not reached, to resolve the dispute by deciding the claims brought to the tribunal by the parties.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In addition to its responsibilities in relation to disputes brought to the tribunal for resolution, the tribunal may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: provide the public with information on dispute resolution processes generally, and
make its online dispute resolution services available to the public generally.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: General authority of tribunal — claim categories
bcl:section.bcl:text: The tribunal may, in accordance with this Act, adjudicate the following claim categories:

bcl:text.#text: claims in relation to a relevant enactment, under Division 2  of Part 10 ;
claims in relation to the , under Division 3  of Part 10;
claims in relation to the , under Division 4  of Part 10;
claims in relation to the , under Division 5  of Part 10;
claims in relation to the , under Division 6  of Part 10;
claims in respect of accidents, as defined in section 132 , under Division 7  of Part 10;
claims in relation to the , under Division 8  of Part 10.

bcl:part.bcl:text: How to Bring a Matter to the Tribunal

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Asking the tribunal to resolve a claim

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who has a claim that is within the jurisdiction of the tribunal may, in accordance with this Part, make a request to the tribunal asking the tribunal to resolve the claim.
A person may not make a request for tribunal resolution if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the applicable Act in respect of the claim describes a class of persons who may make a request for tribunal resolution, and
the person is not in the described class of persons.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A request for tribunal resolution must be made

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in a manner required or authorized under the rules, and
with payment of any applicable fees for the case management phase and the tribunal hearing phase.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: [Repealed 2018-17-6.]

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Use of online dispute resolution services may be required before request accepted
bcl:section.bcl:text: If required under the rules, before a person makes a request for tribunal resolution, the person must attempt to resolve the dispute using online dispute resolution services provided by the tribunal.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Initiating notice

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: On receiving a request for resolution, the tribunal must give the initiating party an initiating notice if, on initial review,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the claim appears to be within the jurisdiction of the tribunal,
the request for resolution appears, on its face, to disclose a reasonable claim, and
the claim meets all of the other requirements under this Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The tribunal may give an amended initiating notice.

bcl:text.in:desc: [general authority for tribunal to refuse to resolve claim or dispute]
bcl:text.#text: If the tribunal decides to give an initiating notice under subsection (1), this decision has no binding effect and, for certainty, does not preclude a subsequent decision by the tribunal not to resolve the claim under section 11 .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the tribunal decides not to give an initiating notice under subsection (1), the tribunal must notify the initiating party and, on request, give reasons.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Giving and responding to initiating notice

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The tribunal may resolve a claim only if the initiating party serves, or is deemed to have served, in accordance with the rules, a copy of the initiating notice to all persons against whom the claim is made.
On being served, or being deemed to have been served, with an initiating notice, a person must make a response in accordance with the rules.
If none of the persons served, or deemed to have been served, with an initiating notice make a response within the time required by the rules, the tribunal

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: must give the initiating party notice that none of the persons served, or deemed to have been served, made a response, and

in:desc: [claims to be resolved must be within tribunal authority]
[general authority for tribunal to refuse to resolve claim or dispute]
[cancellation of final decision or dismissal order under section 36]
bcl:text.#text: may, subject to sections 10 , 11 (1)  and 37 , proceed to adjudicate the dispute in accordance with any applicable rules.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If one or more of the persons served, or deemed to have been served, with an initiating notice make a response within the time required by the rules, the tribunal may do one of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: determine under section 10 (1) that the tribunal does not have jurisdiction over the claim;
refuse to resolve the claim under section 11 (1);
proceed to the case management phase.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Repealed
bcl:section.bcl:text: [Repealed 2015-16-5.]

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Government as party

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The government may not be a party to a tribunal proceeding unless the tribunal proceeding is in relation to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a claim over which the tribunal has exclusive jurisdiction,
an accident claim, or
a claim in a class of claims that is prescribed by regulation.

bcl:text.#text: If the government is a responding party to a tribunal proceeding referred to in subsection (1), the  applies.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Claims to be resolved must be within tribunal authority

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The tribunal must refuse to resolve a claim that it considers is not within the jurisdiction of the tribunal.

bcl:text: may be amended to remove the issues that are not within the tribunal's jurisdiction.

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: one or more issues that are within the tribunal's jurisdiction, and
one or more issues that are not within the tribunal's jurisdiction

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: General authority for tribunal to refuse to resolve claim or dispute

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The tribunal may refuse to resolve a claim or a dispute within its jurisdiction if it considers that any of the following apply:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the claim or the dispute

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: would be more appropriate for another legally binding process or dispute resolution process, or
has been resolved through a legally binding process or other dispute resolution process;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the request for resolution does not disclose a reasonable claim or is an abuse of process;
issues in the claim or the dispute are too complex for the dispute resolution process of the tribunal or otherwise impractical for the tribunal to case manage or resolve;

bcl:text.#text: resolving the claim or the dispute may involve a constitutional question or the application of the ;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the tribunal is satisfied that it has been established, on the basis of satisfactory evidence, that the claim or the dispute is beyond the jurisdiction of the tribunal.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The tribunal may exercise authority under this section

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: at the time of considering a request for tribunal resolution, or
in the case of a request that has been accepted, at any time before the tribunal makes the final decision resolving the dispute.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the tribunal refuses to resolve a dispute under this section, it must notify the person making the request or the parties, as applicable, of the refusal and the reason for the refusal.

bcl:text.in:desc: [restrictions in relation to court and other proceedings — when tribunal proceeding starts]
bcl:text.#text: If the tribunal refuses to resolve a dispute under this section after the tribunal proceeding respecting the dispute has started, section 15  no longer applies in relation to the claims that were to be resolved by the tribunal proceeding.

bcl:text.#text: The  applies to a claim, and, for that purpose,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a reference to a claim in that Act is deemed to include a claim under this Act, and
a reference to a court proceeding in that Act is deemed to include a tribunal proceeding.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Limitation period does not run after request for tribunal resolution

bcl:text.in:desc: [asking the tribunal to resolve a claim]
bcl:text.#text: The basic limitation period and the ultimate limitation period under the  that are applicable to a claim do not run after a request is made under section 4  of this Act for the tribunal to resolve the claim.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Time limit — certain claims brought or continued in court

bcl:text.#text: Unless the court orders otherwise, a party may not bring or continue a claim in a court, which claim may be brought or continued under section 16.4 (1) , more than 28 days after whichever of the following dates is applicable:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the date on which the party receives notice of the tribunal's decision

bcl:text.#text: not to give an initiating notice under section 6 ,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: refusing to resolve the claim under

bcl:text.in:desc: [claims to be resolved must be within tribunal authority]
bcl:text.#text: section 10 , or

bcl:text.in:desc: [general authority for tribunal to refuse to resolve claim or dispute]
bcl:text.#text: section 11 , or

bcl:text.in:desc: [limited jurisdiction and discretion to decline jurisdiction to apply the Human Rights Code]
bcl:text.#text: declining jurisdiction in respect of the claim under section 114 ;

bcl:text.in:desc: [court may order that tribunal not adjudicate claim]
bcl:text.#text: the date of a court order under section 16.2  that the tribunal not adjudicate the claim;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: [Repealed 2022-6-1.]

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Time limit — court determination about matters within jurisdiction of tribunal

in:desc: [asking the tribunal to resolve a claim]
[court must stay or dismiss certain proceedings]
bcl:text.#text: Unless the tribunal or the court orders otherwise, a party may not make a request under section 4  asking the tribunal to resolve a claim more than 28 days after the date of a court order under section 16.1  staying or dismissing, as applicable, a court proceeding under that section.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Time limit — suspension during certain court processes
bcl:section.bcl:text: A time limit of 28 days established under section 13.2 or 13.3 does not run during the following periods:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: from the date a party requests judicial review of a decision of the tribunal until the date of the decision by the court;
from the date a party files a notice of appeal of a court order that relates to the claim until the date of the decision by the court.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Time limit — determination of extent of responsibility for accident

in:desc: [asking the tribunal to resolve a claim]
[determination of extent of responsibility for accident]
bcl:text.#text: A party may not make a request under section 4  asking the tribunal to resolve a claim referred to in section 133 (1) (d)  more than the prescribed number of days after the date of a prescribed event.

Repealed
