bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Restrictions in relation to court and other proceedings — when tribunal proceeding starts

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to this Division, once a tribunal proceeding is started,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a party to the tribunal proceeding may not commence, against another party to the tribunal proceeding, a court proceeding or other legally binding process in relation to an issue or claim that is to be resolved in the tribunal proceeding, and

if a party has already commenced a process referred to in paragraph (a) against another party to the tribunal proceeding, the parties must adjourn or suspend the process while the tribunal proceeding is continuing.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For certainty, except as otherwise provided in this Division, nothing in this section operates to prevent a person from commencing or continuing a legally binding process in respect of a claim until a tribunal proceeding respecting the claim is started.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Repealed
Court must stay or dismiss certain proceedings

bcl:text.#text: Subject to subsection (2) and section 16.4 (1) and (2) , if, in a court proceeding, the court determines that all matters are within the jurisdiction of the tribunal, the court must,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of a claim within the exclusive jurisdiction of the tribunal, dismiss the proceeding,

in the case of a claim in respect of which the tribunal is to be considered to have specialized expertise, dismiss the proceeding unless it is not in the interests of justice and fairness for the tribunal to adjudicate the claim, or
in any other case, stay or dismiss the proceeding, as the court considers appropriate, unless it is not in the interests of justice and fairness for the tribunal to adjudicate the claim.

bcl:text.in:desc: [claims within jurisdiction of tribunal for accident claims]
bcl:text.#text: Subject to section 16.4 (1) and (2), if, in a court proceeding, a party alleges that a matter in a proceeding before the court relates to a minor injury within the jurisdiction of the tribunal under section 133 (1) (b) or (c) , the court must stay the proceeding until the tribunal determines, as applicable,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of an accident claim under section 133 (1) (b), whether an injury is a minor injury, and

in the case of an accident claim under section 133 (1) (c), unless it is not in the interests of justice and fairness for the tribunal to make the determination, whether a party has established that there is a substantial likelihood that damages will exceed the tribunal limit amount.

bcl:text.#text: For the purposes of subsection (2),  and  have the same meaning as in section 132 .

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Court may order that tribunal not adjudicate claim

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (2), the court may order that the tribunal not adjudicate a claim that is or purports to be in one of the claim categories if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the tribunal does not have jurisdiction to adjudicate the claim, or
it is not in the interests of justice and fairness for the tribunal to adjudicate the claim.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (1) (b) does not apply if the tribunal has exclusive jurisdiction in respect of the claim.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Considerations in the interest of justice and fairness

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of sections 16.1 (1) and 16.2 (1), when deciding whether it is in the interests of justice and fairness for the tribunal to adjudicate a claim, the court may consider the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: whether an issue raised by the claim or dispute is of such importance that the claim or dispute would benefit from being adjudicated by that court to establish a precedent;

bcl:text.#text: whether an issue raised by the claim or dispute relates to a constitutional question or the ;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: whether an issue raised by the claim or dispute is sufficiently complex to benefit from being adjudicated by that court;
whether all of the parties to the claim or dispute agree that the claim or dispute should not be adjudicated by the tribunal;
whether the claim or dispute should be heard together with a claim or dispute currently before that court;
whether the use of electronic communication tools in the adjudication process of the tribunal would be unfair to a party in a way that cannot be accommodated by the tribunal.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of section 16.1 (2), when deciding whether it is in the interests of justice and fairness for the tribunal to make the determination referred to in that subsection, the court may consider the principle of proportionality.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Bringing or continuing claim in court

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to this section, a person may not bring or continue, as the case may be, a claim that is within the jurisdiction of the tribunal as a claim in a court unless one or more of the following apply:

bcl:text.#text: the tribunal decides not to give an initiating notice under section 6 ;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the tribunal refuses to resolve the claim under

bcl:text.in:desc: [claims to be resolved must be within tribunal authority]
bcl:text.#text: section 10 , or

bcl:text.in:desc: [general authority for tribunal to refuse to resolve claim or dispute]
bcl:text.#text: section 11 ;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the court orders under section 16.2 that the tribunal not adjudicate the claim;
[Repealed 2022-6-3.]

bcl:text.in:desc: [limited jurisdiction and discretion to decline jurisdiction to apply the Human Rights Code]
bcl:text.#text: the tribunal declines jurisdiction in respect of the claim under section 114 ;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the claim is a counterclaim to a notice of claim or a notice of civil claim, as applicable, filed in the court;
the person is in a class of persons prescribed by regulation.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person may bring or continue, as the case may be, the following claims as a proceeding in the Supreme Court, even if none of the circumstances referred to in subsection (1) (a) to (f) have occurred:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a tribunal small claim;

bcl:text.in:desc: [claims within jurisdiction of tribunal for accident claims]
bcl:text.#text: an accident claim described in section 133 (1) (c) , if all parties consent;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an intimate image protection claim.

bcl:text: If, in respect of a claim that is otherwise within the jurisdiction of the tribunal, the tribunal
a party must seek judicial review of the decision before the party may file notice of the same claim in court.

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: decides not to give an initiating notice solely for the reason that the requirement in section 6 (1) (b) has not been met, or
refuses to resolve the claim solely for the reason described in section 11 (1) (b),

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Tribunal proceeding processes

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A tribunal proceeding has two phases,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the case management phase, and
the tribunal hearing phase.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In the case management phase, resolution by agreement between the parties is facilitated and preparations are made for the tribunal hearing should one be required.
In the tribunal hearing phase, the dispute is heard and the tribunal gives a final decision to resolve the dispute if it is not resolved in the case management phase.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Nature of tribunal proceeding
bcl:section.bcl:text: A tribunal proceeding is to be conducted with as little formality and technicality and with as much speed as permitted by the requirements of this Act, the rules and a proper consideration of the issues in the dispute.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Use of electronic communication tools
bcl:section.bcl:text: The tribunal may use electronic communication tools in conducting all or part of a tribunal proceeding, and may require or authorize parties or other persons to use electronic communication tools provided by the tribunal in relation to tribunal proceedings or other dispute resolution services provided by the tribunal.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: General rule that parties to represent themselves

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Unless otherwise provided under this Act, the parties are to represent themselves in a tribunal proceeding.
A party may be represented by a lawyer or another individual with authority to bind the party in relation to the dispute if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the party is a child or a person with impaired capacity,
the rules permit the party to be represented, or
the tribunal, in the interests of justice and fairness, permits the party to be represented.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Without limiting the authority of the tribunal under subsection (2) (c), the tribunal may consider the following as circumstances supporting giving the permission:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: another party is represented in the proceeding;
the other parties have agreed to the representation.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person representing a party in a tribunal proceeding must be a lawyer unless

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the rules otherwise permit, or
the tribunal is satisfied that the person being proposed to represent the party is an appropriate person to do this.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In the case of a party that is a corporation, partnership or other form of organization or office with capacity to be a party to a court proceeding, the person acting for the party in the tribunal proceeding must be

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a director, officer or partner of the party,
an individual permitted under the rules, or
an individual permitted by the tribunal.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Lawyer representation in respect of accident claims or intimate image protection claims
bcl:section.bcl:text: Without limiting section 20, a party may, as of right, be represented by a lawyer in a tribunal proceeding in respect of an accident claim or an intimate image protection claim.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Repealed
Parties may request consent dismissal order

bcl:text: On request of all parties to a dispute, made
the tribunal may make an order dismissing some or all claims in the dispute.

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: at any time during the case management phase, or
at any time during the tribunal hearing phase before the tribunal gives its final decision in the dispute,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A dismissal order under subsection (1) is a final decision of the tribunal resolving the specified claims.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Case manager role

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The role of a case manager is to assist in the resolution of disputes, including by

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: assisting the parties in reaching resolution by agreement through facilitated settlement as provided in the rules,
reviewing the claims in a dispute and assisting the parties in identifying the facts relevant to resolving the dispute and the issues to be decided,
so far as is practicable, determining the evidence or other information that will assist in resolving a dispute, and
making a recommendation to the tribunal as to the process to be used in hearing the dispute, if the tribunal has jurisdiction to do so.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In the case management phase, facilitated settlement and preparations for a tribunal hearing may be conducted at the same time.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Case managers assigned to dispute

bcl:text.in:desc: [assignment of case managers and tribunal panels]
bcl:text.#text: The case manager for a dispute may be a tribunal member or other tribunal officer as assigned in accordance with section 80 .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For certainty, more than one tribunal officer may act as case manager in relation to the same dispute.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Dispute resolution services that may be used

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A case manager has authority

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to determine, in accordance with the rules, which facilitated settlement service is to be used in the case management phase for a particular dispute, and
to require the parties to participate in facilitated settlement services.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Facilitated settlement may be conducted in person, in writing, by telephone, videoconferencing or email, or through use of other electronic communication tools, or by any combination of those means.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Consent resolution orders if parties resolve issues or claims by agreement

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If, in the case management phase, the parties to a dispute reach a resolution by agreement on any or all of the issues or claims in the dispute, they may ask the case manager to prepare a draft consent resolution order respecting the issues or claims.
If the case manager prepares a draft consent resolution order and the parties agree to the draft order, the order is to be presented to the tribunal for approval as an order of the tribunal.
If the tribunal declines to approve a draft consent resolution order, it must provide the parties with reasons for doing this.
If the tribunal approves the draft consent resolution order, that order becomes a final decision of the tribunal resolving the specified issues or claims.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Case manager may provide neutral evaluation of dispute

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to the rules, the case manager may provide to the parties either or both of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a non-binding neutral evaluation of the claims in the dispute, and
the case manager's views on how the court or tribunal would likely resolve the dispute if it proceeded to a court or tribunal hearing.

in:desc: [case manager may make recommendation for resolution if parties consent]
[case manager may act as tribunal if parties consent]
bcl:text.#text: Subject to sections 28  and 29 , neither the parties to a dispute nor the case manager may disclose to the court or tribunal any evaluation or views provided under subsection (1).

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Case manager may make recommendation for resolution if parties consent

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the parties to a dispute consent, the case manager may make a recommendation to the tribunal as to the final decision resolving the dispute.
A recommendation may be in the form of a draft final decision, or a draft final decision and draft order giving effect to the final decision, for consideration by the tribunal.
In hearing the dispute, the tribunal must consider, but is not required to follow, a recommendation made under this section.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Case manager may act as tribunal in providing direct resolution if parties agree

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the case manager for a dispute is a tribunal member, the case manager may, during the case management phase, offer to act as the tribunal in accordance with this section.
If the parties agree to this direct resolution of any or all of the issues or claims in the dispute, the case manager may

bcl:text.in:desc: [assignment of case managers and tribunal panel]
bcl:text.#text: act as the tribunal panel in resolving those issues or claims without assignment under section 80 , and
proceed to resolve the issues or claims under Division 2  of Part 5 , but on the basis of the information received by the case manager and without any further case management or hearing.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Unresolved claims in dispute proceed to tribunal hearing
bcl:section.bcl:text: If a claim has not been resolved during the case management phase, the claim is to proceed to resolution by tribunal hearing.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Addition of appropriate parties

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the case manager considers that one or more other persons should properly be parties to a dispute, the case manager may provide the current parties with an opportunity to have those other persons added as parties in accordance with the rules and with any directions by the case manager.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Preparation of case and evidence

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of preparing the dispute for resolution by the tribunal, the case manager may direct any or all parties to do the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: provide information respecting

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the issues in the dispute,
the position of the parties in relation to those issues, and
the resolution that is being requested;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: provide evidence respecting a matter that is relevant to an issue in the dispute, including requiring the evidence to be provided on oath or affirmation or in a manner authorized under the rules;
produce a record or other thing in the party's possession or control that is relevant to an issue in the dispute;
prepare an agreed statement of facts;
arrange for the preparation of expert evidence, including

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: by requiring the parties to do this jointly,
by limiting the number of experts a party may call, or
by limiting the giving of expert evidence in respect of one or more issues in a claim to an expert appointed by the tribunal.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The tribunal may make an order requiring compliance with a direction under this section.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Party may prepare summons to require other persons to provide evidence

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A party to a dispute may prepare and serve a summons, in a form authorized by the rules, requiring a person

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to provide evidence that is relevant to an issue in the dispute, on oath or affirmation or in a manner authorized under the rules, by attending or participating in the tribunal hearing or by providing the evidence for use in the tribunal hearing, or
to produce, for the tribunal, the summoning party or another party, a record or other thing that is relevant to an issue in the dispute and is in the person's possession or control.

bcl:text.#text: The authority under subsection (1) may not be exercised in relation to evidence that is inadmissible under section 42 (2) .

bcl:text.in:desc: [tribunal may require persons to provide evidence — allocation of expenses]
bcl:text.#text: Subject to an order under section 34 (1) (f) , the party that served a summons under this section is responsible for the expenses and witness fees that are payable in relation to the summons.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A summons under this section may be cancelled by the tribunal in accordance with the rules.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Tribunal may require persons to provide evidence

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The tribunal may, at any time during the case management phase or tribunal hearing phase for a dispute, make orders as follows:

bcl:text.in:desc: [party may prepare summons to require other persons to provide evidence]
bcl:text.#text: requiring a party to prepare and serve a summons under section 33 ;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: requiring a person to comply with a summons served by a party under section 33;
requiring a person to provide evidence that is relevant to an issue in the dispute, including by requiring evidence to be provided on oath or affirmation or in a manner authorized under the rules;
requiring a person to produce a record or other thing that is relevant to an issue in the dispute and is in the person's possession or control;
in the case of an order directed at an organization, requiring any directors or officers of the organization to cause the organization to comply with the order;

making a party responsible for, or allocating between the parties responsibility for, the expenses and witness fees that are payable in relation to an order under paragraph (c) or (d) or a summons under section 33.

bcl:text.#text: The authority under subsection (1) may not be exercised in relation to evidence that is inadmissible under section 42 (2) .

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Referral to tribunal if claim has no reasonable likelihood of success

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: At any time in the case management phase, if the case manager considers that a claim in a dispute has no reasonable likelihood of success or gives rise to an abuse of process, the case manager may,

bcl:text.in:desc: [assignment of case managers and tribunal panels]
bcl:text.#text: if the case manager is a tribunal member, exercise tribunal authority under this section without assignment under section 80 , and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in any case, refer the claim to the tribunal.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a claim is to be dealt with under this section, the tribunal must review the claim in accordance with the rules and may, following the review,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: make an order dismissing the claim if the tribunal considers that the claim is frivolous, vexatious or an abuse of process, or
direct that the claim is to continue to be dealt with by the tribunal proceeding.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The tribunal must give reasons for dismissing a claim under subsection (2) (a).

If the reasons provided under subsection (3) are not formal written reasons, the party whose claim has been dismissed may request that the tribunal provide formal written reasons for the decision, in which case the tribunal must provide those reasons within the time period established by the rules.

bcl:text.#text: A dismissal order under subsection (2) (a) may include a requirement for payment, as described in section 49 , by the party who made the claim that is being dismissed.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Referral to tribunal for non-compliance

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: This section applies if a party to a dispute fails to comply with any of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: this Act or the regulations;
the rules in relation to the case management phase for the dispute, including any time limits specified for taking actions;
an order of the tribunal made during the case management phase.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The case manager may, after giving notice to the non-compliant party, refer the dispute to the tribunal for resolution.
If a dispute is referred to the tribunal under this section, the tribunal may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: proceed to hear the dispute in accordance with any applicable rules,
make an order dismissing a claim in the dispute that is made by the non-compliant party, or
refuse to resolve a claim of the non-compliant party or refuse to resolve the dispute.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the tribunal makes a dismissal order under subsection (3) (b),

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the tribunal must give reasons for the order, and

bcl:text.#text: the order may include a requirement for payment, as described in section 49 , by the party referred to in subsection (1).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the reasons provided under subsection (4) (a) are not formal written reasons, the party whose claim was dismissed may request that the tribunal provide formal written reasons for the decision, in which case the tribunal must provide those reasons within the time period established by the rules.
If the tribunal refuses under subsection (3) (c) to resolve a claim or the dispute,

bcl:text.in:desc: [restrictions in relation to court and other proceedings — when tribunal proceeding starts]
bcl:text.#text: section 15  ceases to apply in relation to the claim or dispute, as applicable,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: any further request for tribunal resolution in relation to a claim that was refused may be made only with leave of the tribunal, and
the tribunal must certify that case management of all of the claims in the dispute is completed.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Cancellation of final decision or dismissal order under section 36

bcl:text.#text: If, under section 36 , the tribunal makes

bcl:text: that party may request that the tribunal cancel the final decision or order.

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a final decision following a hearing, or
a dismissal order respecting a claim of the non-compliant party,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A request under this section must be made in accordance with the rules and with payment of any applicable fee.

The tribunal may, in accordance with the rules, order that the final decision or dismissal order is cancelled if satisfied that the circumstances established by the rules apply, in which case the dispute is to be resolved by continuing the tribunal proceeding.
If a final decision is cancelled under this section, the order giving effect to the final decision is cancelled.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: General tribunal authority in conducting hearings
bcl:section.bcl:text: The procedure for a tribunal hearing in relation to a dispute is at the discretion of the tribunal, subject to this Act and the rules.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: How tribunal hearings are conducted

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In resolving a dispute, the tribunal may conduct a hearing in writing, by telephone, videoconferencing or email, or through use of other electronic communication tools, or by any combination of those means.
It is not necessary for the means of communication referred to in subsection (1) to allow all parties to the dispute to take part at the same time.

The tribunal may hold an in-person hearing if the tribunal considers that the nature of the dispute or that extraordinary circumstances make an in-person hearing necessary in the interests of justice.
Subject to an order under subsection (5), an in-person hearing must be open to the public.
The tribunal may, by order,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: impose restrictions on a person's continued participation in or attendance at a tribunal hearing, and
exclude a person from further participation in or attendance at a tribunal hearing until the tribunal orders otherwise.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Notice of hearing
bcl:section.bcl:text: The tribunal must give notice to the parties as to the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: when the tribunal hearing is to be started;
the means by which it is to be conducted;
if applicable, where the hearing is to be conducted;
if applicable, the times by which steps in the hearing are to be completed and by whom;
any other information required to be provided under the rules.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Consent resolution orders if parties resolve issues or claims by agreement

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If, in the tribunal hearing phase, the parties to a dispute reach a resolution by agreement on any or all of the issues or claims in the dispute, they may ask the tribunal to approve a consent resolution order respecting the issues or claims.
If the tribunal approves the consent resolution order, that order is a final decision of the tribunal resolving the specified issues or claims.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Evidence in tribunal hearing

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In conducting a hearing, the tribunal may do any or all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: receive, and accept as evidence, information that it considers relevant, necessary and appropriate, whether or not the information would be admissible in a court of law;
ask questions of the parties and witnesses;
inform itself in any other way it considers appropriate.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The tribunal is not bound by the rules of evidence, but may not admit evidence that is inadmissible in a court because of a privilege under the law of evidence or otherwise.
Unless otherwise required under the rules or by the tribunal, evidence to be provided in a tribunal hearing may be provided in electronic form.

Nothing in this section overrides the provisions of this or any other Act that expressly limit the extent to which or purposes for which any oral testimony, information, records or things may be admitted or used in evidence.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Repealed
Recording tribunal proceedings

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The tribunal may make an electronic or other recording of its proceedings or transcribe its proceedings.
The tribunal's recording or transcription of a proceeding must be considered to be correct and to constitute part of the record of the proceeding.
If, by a mechanical or human failure or other accident, the recording or transcription of a proceeding is destroyed, interrupted or incomplete, the validity of the proceeding is not affected.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Referral back to case management phase
bcl:section.bcl:text: The tribunal may direct that a dispute be referred back to the case management phase if, in the course of a tribunal hearing,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the tribunal considers that one or more persons should properly be parties to the dispute, or
other circumstances established by the rules apply.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Tribunal must give final decision following hearing

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Following a tribunal hearing, the tribunal must, within the applicable time period, if any, established by the rules,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: give its final decision in resolving the claims in the dispute,
give reasons for the decision, and
subject to this Act and the rules, make any order the tribunal considers is required to give effect to the decision.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If an order giving effect to a final decision is given orally, a written record of the order must be given to the parties within the time period established by the rules.

If the reasons provided under subsection (1) (b) are not formal written reasons, a party to the dispute may request that the tribunal provide formal written reasons for the decision, in which case the tribunal must provide those reasons within the time period established by the rules.
The chair may extend a time period that is otherwise applicable under this section.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Notice of final decision

bcl:text.in:desc: [tribunal must give final decision following hearing]
bcl:text.#text: The tribunal must, within the applicable time period referred to in section 46 (1) ,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the final decision is not given orally, give notice of the final decision to all parties to the dispute, and
in all cases, provide the parties with access to, or a copy of, the final decision and any order giving effect to the final decision.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Order giving effect to final decision

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The tribunal may make an order giving effect to a final decision on terms and conditions the tribunal considers appropriate.
If an order referred to in subsection (1) includes an order for the payment of money, the order must set out the principal amount payable.

bcl:text.#text: The  applies to the tribunal as if it were a court.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The tribunal may make an order varying the terms and conditions of an order giving effect to a final decision, but may not vary the final decision.
[Repealed 2022-6-4.]

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Repealed
Order for payment of expenses

bcl:text.#text: An order under section 48  may include a requirement for one party to pay to another party to the dispute some or all of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the fees paid under this Act by the other party in relation to the dispute, and
any other reasonable expenses and charges that the tribunal considers directly relate to the conduct of the proceeding.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For certainty, expenses and charges referred to in subsection (1) (b) include amounts payable under

bcl:text.in:desc: [party may prepare summons to require other persons to provide evidence]
bcl:text.#text: section 33 (3) , or

bcl:text.in:desc: [tribunal may require persons to provide evidence — allocation of expenses]
bcl:text.#text: section 34 (1) (f) .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A requirement included in an order under subsection (1) may be subject to limits or restrictions prescribed by regulation, which may be different for different classes of claim categories, disputes, claims, issues, parties, insurers and circumstances, as established by the regulations.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: When final decision is effective

bcl:text.#text: Unless otherwise specified by the tribunal, a final decision under section 46  is effective,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of a final decision given orally, when it is given, and

bcl:text.#text: in the case of a final decision given other than orally, on the date that notice is given under section 47 .

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Amendment of final decision or order to clarify

bcl:text: Subject to the rules, the tribunal may amend
for the purpose of clarifying the decision or order.

bcl:text.#text: a final decision under section 46 , or

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an order giving effect to a final decision

in:desc: [order giving effect to final decision — authority to vary terms and conditions]
bcl:text.#text: The tribunal may not amend a final decision or order referred to in subsection (1) other than as provided under this section, section 48 (4)  or section 64 .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: This section must not be construed as limiting the tribunal's ability, on request of a party, to reopen a tribunal proceeding in order to cure a jurisdictional defect.

bcl:division.bcl:text: Tribunal Authority If Party Does Not Participate

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Tribunal may hear or dismiss claims or dispute if party does not participate

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a party does not attend or otherwise participate in a tribunal hearing at a time set for the hearing, the tribunal may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: proceed to hear and resolve the dispute in accordance with any applicable rules, or
make an order dismissing a claim in the dispute that is made by the non-participating party.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the tribunal makes a dismissal order under subsection (1) (b),

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the tribunal must give reasons for the order, and

bcl:text.#text: the order may include a requirement for payment, as described in section 49 , by the non-participating party referred to in subsection (1) of this section.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the reasons provided under subsection (2) (a) are not formal written reasons, the party whose claim was dismissed may request that the tribunal provide formal written reasons for the decision, in which case the tribunal must provide those reasons within the time period established by the rules.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Cancellation of final decision or dismissal order made in absence of party

bcl:text.in:desc: [tribunal may hear or dismiss claims or dispute if party does not participate]
bcl:text.#text: If, under section 52 , the tribunal makes

bcl:text: that party may request that the tribunal cancel the final decision or order.

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a final decision following a hearing, or
a dismissal order respecting a claim of the non-participating party,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A request under this section must be made in accordance with the rules and with payment of any applicable fee.

The tribunal may, in accordance with the rules, cancel the final decision or dismissal order if satisfied that the circumstances established by the rules apply, in which case the dispute is to be resolved by continuing the tribunal proceeding.
If a final decision is cancelled, the order giving effect to the final decision is cancelled.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Repealed
Repealed
bcl:section.bcl:text: [Repealed 2022-6-6.]

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Repealed
Time limit for application for judicial review

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An application for judicial review of a decision of the tribunal must be commenced within 60 days of the date the decision is given.

Despite subsection (1), either before or after expiration of the time, the Supreme Court may extend the time for making the application on terms the Supreme Court considers proper, if the Supreme Court is satisfied that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: there are serious grounds for relief,
there is a reasonable explanation for the delay, and
no substantial prejudice or hardship will result to a person affected by the delay.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Standard of review if tribunal has exclusive jurisdiction or specialized expertise

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The tribunal must be considered to be an expert tribunal relative to the courts in relation to a decision of the tribunal

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: concerning a claim within the exclusive jurisdiction of the tribunal, or

bcl:text.in:desc: [claims within jurisdiction of tribunal for accident claims]
bcl:text.#text: concerning a claim in respect of which the tribunal is to be considered to have specialized expertise, other than a decision of the tribunal concerning a claim described in section 133 (1) (c) .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: On an application for judicial review of a decision of the tribunal for which the tribunal must be considered to be an expert tribunal, the standard of review to be applied is as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a finding of fact or law or an exercise of discretion by the tribunal must not be interfered with unless it is patently unreasonable;
questions about the application of common law rules of natural justice and procedural fairness must be decided having regard to whether, in all of the circumstances, the tribunal acted fairly;
for all matters other than those identified in paragraphs (a) and (b), the standard of review to be applied to the tribunal's decision is correctness.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Standard of review — other tribunal decisions

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: This section applies to an application for judicial review of a decision of the tribunal other than a decision for which the tribunal must be considered to be an expert tribunal under section 56.7.
The standard of review to be applied to a decision of the tribunal is correctness for all questions except those respecting

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a finding of fact,
the exercise of discretion, or
the application of common law rules of natural justice and procedural fairness.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The Supreme Court must not set aside a finding of fact by the tribunal unless

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: there is no evidence to support the finding, or
in light of all the evidence, the finding is otherwise unreasonable.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The Supreme Court must not set aside a discretionary decision of the tribunal unless it is patently unreasonable.
Questions about the application of common law rules of natural justice and procedural fairness must be decided having regard to whether, in all of the circumstances, the tribunal acted fairly.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Discretionary decision — patently unreasonable
bcl:section.bcl:text: For the purposes of sections 56.7 (2) (a) and 56.8 (4), a discretionary decision is patently unreasonable if the discretion

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is exercised arbitrarily or in bad faith,
is exercised for an improper purpose,
is based entirely or predominantly on irrelevant factors, or
fails to take statutory requirements into account.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Enforcement by filing in Supreme Court

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A final decision of the tribunal in relation to a claim category, other than a tribunal small claim, may be enforced by filing, in the Supreme Court, a validated copy of an order giving effect to the final decision.
An order filed under subsection (1) has the same force and effect, and all proceedings may be taken on it, as if it were a judgment of the Supreme Court.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Enforcement by filing in Provincial Court

bcl:text.#text: A validated copy of an order referred to in section 57  may be filed in the Provincial Court if
is within the monetary limit for claims under the .

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the order is for financial compensation or the return of personal property, and
as applicable,

bcl:text.#text: the principal amount set out under section 48 (2) , or

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the value of the personal property

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An order filed under subsection (1) has the same force and effect, and all proceedings may be taken on it, as if it were a judgment of the Provincial Court.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Enforcement of small claims decisions

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A consent resolution order in relation to a tribunal small claim may be enforced by filing, in the Provincial Court, a validated copy of the order.
A final decision of the tribunal in relation to a tribunal small claim may be enforced by filing, in the Provincial Court, a validated copy of the order giving effect to the final decision.
[Repealed 2022-6-7.]
An order filed under this section has the same force and effect, and all proceedings may be taken on it, as if it were a judgment of the Provincial Court.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Enforcement of tribunal decision by other person

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A final decision of the tribunal in relation to a claim adjudicated by the tribunal may, unless the court orders otherwise, be enforced under this Part by a person who was not a party to the claim if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the claim is a strata property claim, or
the person is within a prescribed class of persons.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a person referred to in subsection (1) enforces a final decision under subsection (1), the person is deemed to be a party for the purposes of this Act.
Subsection (1) does not apply to a tribunal small claim.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Cancellation of tribunal order

bcl:text.in:desc: [cancellation of final decision or dismissal order under section 36]
bcl:text.#text: If the tribunal cancels under section 37  an order that has been filed under this Part, the party that filed the cancelled order must not take any further steps to enforce that order and must take the steps necessary to discontinue any enforcement process.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Enforcement of tribunal orders by proceeding for contempt

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who fails or refuses to comply with an order of the tribunal is liable, on application to the Supreme Court, to be punished for contempt as if in breach of an order or judgment of the Supreme Court.
Subsection (1) does not limit the conduct for which the Supreme Court may make a finding of contempt in respect of a person's conduct in relation to a tribunal proceeding.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: General tribunal authority in relation to tribunal proceeding

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to this Act and the rules, the tribunal may make any order or give any direction in relation to a tribunal proceeding it thinks necessary to achieve the objects of the tribunal in accordance with its mandate.
The tribunal may make an order under subsection (1) or, unless otherwise provided, under any other provision of this Act

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: on its own initiative,
on request by a party, or
on recommendation by a case manager.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Unless otherwise restricted under this Act, the tribunal may vary or cancel an order that it has made under the Act.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Rules of practice and procedure for tribunal proceedings

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The tribunal may make rules respecting practice and procedure in tribunal proceedings to facilitate the resolution of disputes before it in accordance with its mandate.
Without limiting subsection (1), the tribunal may make rules respecting the following:

bcl:text.#text: the form and content of an initiating notice under section 6  and a response under section 7 ;

bcl:text.in:desc: [general authority for tribunal to refuse to resolve a dispute]
bcl:text.#text: factors supporting a refusal under section 11 ;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: dispute resolution services provided by the tribunal, including rules respecting

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: online dispute resolution services and their use, and
facilitated settlement that may be provided in the case management phase;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: procedures and processes that apply in relation to tribunal proceedings, including rules

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: providing authority to waive or modify a rule in relation to a tribunal proceeding,
establishing times by which actions in a tribunal proceeding are to be taken, including providing authority to extend or shorten established times,
providing authority in relation to adjournments and postponements,
respecting the process to be followed by the tribunal if a court orders it not to facilitate the settlement of, resolve or adjudicate a claim,

bcl:text.in:desc: [proceeding to hearing if a party does not comply with the case management process]
bcl:text.#text: imposing restrictions on evidence and submissions in relation to a tribunal hearing under section 36 (3) (a) ,

bcl:text.in:desc: [tribunal may hear claims or dispute if party does not appear]
bcl:text.#text: respecting procedures and processes that apply to a hearing under section 52 (1) (a) , and
respecting procedures and processes that apply to a claim that is an application made under section 5 of the , including all related matters;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: powers under the Act to make orders and give directions, including rules

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: respecting the process for a party to request that an order or direction be made,
respecting orders available if a party given an initiating notice fails to make a response,
respecting the cancellation of an order given when a party that fails to make a response within the time required by the rules subsequently makes a response, and

in:desc: [cancellation of final decision or dismissal order under section 36]
[cancellation of final decision or dismissal order made in absence of party]
bcl:text.#text: respecting the cancellation of a final decision or order under section 37  or 53 ;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the form, content and manner for giving notices, summons, orders or other information or records, including rules

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: authorizing the service, giving, filing, delivery or other provision to be done through electronic communication tools provided by the tribunal or through other means,
establishing requirements for service, and what is considered to be the address for service, of a party,
authorizing substituted service, and
establishing when a notice, summons, order or other information or record is deemed to have been served on or otherwise given to or received by the tribunal, a party or another person;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the provision, receipt, disclosure and exchange of evidence, other information and records in a tribunal proceeding, including rules

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: respecting how a person providing evidence asserts the truth of the evidence by oath, affirmation or otherwise,
respecting forms of evidence to be provided,
respecting requirements for the preparation of expert witness evidence by a party or jointly by parties,
limiting the number of expert witnesses a party may call or limiting, in respect of one or more issues in a claim, the giving of expert witness evidence to an expert appointed by the tribunal,

bcl:text.in:desc: [party may require other persons to provide evidence]
bcl:text.#text: respecting summonses under section 33 , including establishing witness fees and expenses that are payable in relation to a summons and providing authority for the tribunal to cancel or vary a summons, and

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: authorizing the tribunal to direct how expenses for the provision, receipt, disclosure and exchange are to be allocated between parties;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the participation of parties and other persons in tribunal proceedings, including rules

bcl:text.in:desc: [who may act for corporations and other organizations]
bcl:text.#text: respecting who may act for an organization or office in a tribunal proceeding as referred to in section 20 (5) ,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: respecting representation of a party by a lawyer or other person,
allowing a party or witness to have a supporting person present with the party or witness while participating in a tribunal proceeding, and
respecting authority of the tribunal to allow other persons to participate in a tribunal proceeding;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the consequences of a party's non-compliance with the rules or with a tribunal order, including

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: respecting the process to be followed if a party given an initiating notice fails to make a response, and
respecting the process to be followed if an order is given against a party that fails to make a response within the time required by the rules but that subsequently makes a response;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: establishing a tariff of expenses and charges of a party that may be payable by one party to another party;
respecting the preparation of validated copies of certificates, directions, orders, reasons and final decisions of the tribunal;
respecting communications and records in relation to tribunal proceedings, including rules

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: respecting the use, validity and authenticity of and access to electronic communications and electronic records in relation to tribunal proceedings,
respecting access to and restriction of access to tribunal records by any person, and

bcl:text.in:desc: [tribunal members and staff obligation of confidentiality]
bcl:text.#text: establishing information that is considered to be confidential under section 87 ;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: respecting fees, including rules

bcl:text.#text: establishing fees that may be charged by the tribunal for providing services, other than services for which fees are established by regulation under section 93 (2) (f) ,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: authorizing the tribunal to waive fees applicable under this Act for a person who cannot afford the fees, and
authorizing the tribunal to direct the refund of fees under this Act in circumstances established by the rules;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: rules respecting any other matter for which rules are contemplated by this Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Where a provision of subsection (2) describes a specific matter as being included as part of the authority under that subsection, the inclusion must not be read as limiting the authority of the general description of that authority.
Rules for the tribunal may be different for different classes of claim categories, disputes, claims, issues and circumstances, as established by the rules.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Practice directives

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The chair may issue practice directives consistent with this Act, the rules and the regulations.
The tribunal is not bound by the practice directives in the exercise of its powers or the performance of its duties.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Authority to correct decisions and orders
bcl:section.bcl:text: On its own initiative or on request by a party, the tribunal may amend a decision or order to correct any of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a clerical or typographical error;
an accidental or inadvertent error, omission or other similar mistake;
an arithmetical error made in a computation.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Authority of tribunal members and panels

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An authority conferred under this Act on the tribunal may be exercised by any tribunal member or panel assigned responsibility in relation to the applicable tribunal proceeding.
For certainty, subsection (1) applies to a tribunal member acting as a case manager in relation to the tribunal proceeding.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Authority to administer oaths
bcl:section.bcl:text: If a person is required under this Act to provide evidence or other information on oath or solemn affirmation, a tribunal member or case manager may administer the oath or receive the solemn affirmation.

bcl:division.bcl:text: Appointment of Tribunal Members and Other Staff

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Tribunal chair

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may, after a merit-based process, appoint the chair of the tribunal.
The term of office for the chair must be at least 3 years and not more than 5 years, and the appointment must be on a full-time basis.
The Lieutenant Governor in Council may reappoint the chair for additional terms.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Vice chairs and other members of the tribunal

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may, after a merit-based process and after consultation with the chair, appoint one or more vice chairs of the tribunal.
The Lieutenant Governor in Council may, on the recommendation of the chair after a merit-based process, appoint one or more other tribunal members.
The term of office for the initial appointment of a tribunal member under this section must be at least 2 years and not more than 4 years.
The Lieutenant Governor in Council may reappoint a tribunal member appointed under this section, after a merit-based process, for additional terms of not more than 5 years.
An appointment under this section may be on a full-time basis or part-time basis.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Temporary tribunal members

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to this section, if the tribunal requires additional members, the chair may appoint as a temporary tribunal member a person who would otherwise be qualified for appointment as a tribunal member.
The chair must comply with any conditions and qualifications established under subsection (5).
The term of office for a temporary tribunal member's appointment under this section must not be more than 6 months, and the appointment may be on a full-time basis or part-time basis.
A person may be appointed under this section only twice in any 2-year period.
The Lieutenant Governor in Council may establish conditions and qualifications for appointments under this section.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Acting chair if chair absent or incapacitated

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the chair expects to be absent or is absent, the chair may designate a vice chair as the acting chair for the period that the chair is absent.

Despite subsection (1), if the chair is absent or incapacitated for an extended period, the minister may designate a vice chair as the acting chair for the period that the chair is absent or incapacitated.

bcl:text: If there is authority to make a designation under subsection (1) or (2) but
the chair or minister, as applicable, may designate another tribunal member as the acting chair.

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: there is no vice chair, or
there is a vice chair but the vice chair is not willing or able to act as chair,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person designated under this section has all the powers and may perform all the duties of the chair.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Acting chair if no chair appointed

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the tribunal has no chair, the Lieutenant Governor in Council may appoint a tribunal member, or an individual who would otherwise be qualified for appointment as a tribunal member, as the acting chair for a term of not more than 6 months.
In exceptional circumstances, an individual may be reappointed as the acting chair under subsection (1) for an additional term of not more than 6 months.
A person appointed under this section has all the powers and may perform all the duties of the chair.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Member's absence or incapacitation

bcl:text.#text: If a tribunal member appointed under section 68

bcl:text: the Lieutenant Governor in Council may, after consultation with the chair, appoint another person, who would otherwise be qualified for appointment as a tribunal member, to replace the tribunal member until the member returns to full duty or the member's term expires, whichever comes first.

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: expects to be absent for an extended period, or
is absent or incapacitated for an extended period,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The appointment of a person under subsection (1) is not affected by the tribunal member returning to less than full duty.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Powers after resignation or expiry of term

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a tribunal member resigns or their appointment expires, the chair may authorize the person to continue to exercise powers as a tribunal member in any proceeding over which that person had jurisdiction immediately before the end of the person's term as a tribunal member.
An authorization under subsection (1) continues until a final decision in that proceeding is made.

bcl:text.#text: If an individual performs duties under subsection (1), section 75  applies.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Validity of tribunal acts
bcl:section.bcl:text: An act of the tribunal is not invalid because of a defect that is afterwards discovered in the appointment of a chair, vice chair or member.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Termination for cause
bcl:section.bcl:text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may not terminate the appointment of the chair, a vice chair or another tribunal member except for cause.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Remuneration and benefits for members

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister must, in accordance with the general directives of the Treasury Board, set the remuneration for tribunal members.

In accordance with the general directives of the Treasury Board, tribunal members must be reimbursed for reasonable travelling and out-of-pocket expenses necessarily incurred in carrying out their duties.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Other tribunal officers

bcl:text.#text: Employees necessary to carry out the powers and duties of the tribunal may be appointed under the .

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Other persons engaged or retained by tribunal

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The chair may engage or retain consultants or specialists the tribunal considers necessary to exercise the powers and perform the duties of the tribunal under this Act and may determine their remuneration.
Without limiting subsection (1), the chair may engage or retain persons to conduct facilitated settlement.

bcl:text.#text: The  does not apply to a person engaged or retained under this section.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Authority of chair

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The chair is responsible for the effective management and operation of the tribunal and for the organization and allocation of work among the tribunal members.
Without limiting the authority of the chair, the chair may do any or all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: establish divisions of the tribunal for the purpose of providing efficient and effective dispute resolution services in accordance with the mandate of the tribunal or providing expertise in relation to particular subject matters;
establish a code of practice and performance expectations for tribunal members;
establish templates that are to be used by tribunal members in preparing orders, final decisions and formal written reasons;
establish a process for receiving and dealing with complaints from the public respecting the tribunal.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Chair may establish panels

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The chair may establish panels of one, two or three tribunal members.
If a panel has more than one member,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the chair must designate one of the members as chair of the panel, and
a decision of a majority of the members of a panel is a decision of the tribunal and, in the case of a tie, the decision of the chair of the panel governs.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: There is no restriction on the number of panels that may be engaged in tribunal hearings at the same time.

If a member of a panel is unable for any reason to complete the member's duties, the remaining members of that panel, with consent of the chair of the tribunal, may continue to hear and determine the dispute, and the vacancy does not invalidate the proceeding.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Assignment of case managers and tribunal panels
bcl:section.bcl:text: The chair is responsible for the assignment of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: case managers for a dispute, and
a tribunal panel to act as tribunal for a dispute.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Service improvement surveys
bcl:section.bcl:text: For the purposes of evaluating and improving its services under this Act, the tribunal may conduct surveys in the course of or after providing those services.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Annual report by chair

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: As soon as practicable after the end of the fiscal year of the government, the tribunal must submit to the minister an annual report on the activities of the tribunal, including information respecting the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a review of the operation of the tribunal during the preceding fiscal year;
performance indicators for the preceding fiscal year, including details of the number, nature, time to resolution and outcome of disputes that came before the tribunal during that year;
details of the number and nature of disputes before the tribunal that were outstanding at the end of the preceding fiscal year;

bcl:text.#text: results of surveys conducted under section 81 ;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: details of any trends or special problems that emerged during the preceding fiscal year;
forecasts of the workload of the tribunal in the present fiscal year;
plans for improving the operation of the tribunal in the present fiscal year.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: After receiving an annual report under subsection (1), the minister must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: promptly lay the report before the Legislative Assembly if it is then sitting, or
if the Legislative Assembly is not sitting, file the report with the Clerk of the Legislative Assembly.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Tribunal member duties
bcl:section.bcl:text: Tribunal members must faithfully, honestly and impartially perform their duties.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Immunity protection

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section:

bcl:text.#text: means

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the consideration of requests for tribunal resolution,
the case management phase in relation to a dispute, or
a tribunal hearing in relation to a dispute;

bcl:text.#text: means a tribunal member, a case manager or other tribunal officer, or a person conducting facilitated settlement.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (3), no legal proceeding for damages lies or may be commenced or maintained against a protected person, the tribunal or the government because of anything done or omitted

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the exercise or intended exercise of any power under this Act in relation to a protected function, or
in the performance or intended performance of any duty under this Act in relation to a protected function.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (2) does not apply to a person referred to in that subsection in relation to anything done or omitted by that person in bad faith.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Publication of tribunal orders and other information

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The tribunal must make the following information available to the public, including by making it available on the internet:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the rules of practice and procedure for the tribunal;
any practice directives of the tribunal;
fees that are payable in relation to services provided by the tribunal;

bcl:text.in:desc: [tribunal must give final decision following hearing]
bcl:text.#text: the final decisions of the tribunal under section 46 , except final decisions in respect of parties in default.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The tribunal may make the following available to the public, including by making it available on the internet:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: information respecting disputes that are current tribunal proceedings, including, without limiting this, the parties and claims in the disputes and the status of the tribunal proceedings;
orders of the tribunal;
the final decisions of the tribunal under section 46 in respect of parties in default;
formal written reasons for final decisions or a record of such reasons.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Protection of personal information

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The tribunal must protect personal information in its custody or under its control by making reasonable security arrangements against such risks as unauthorized access, collection, use, disclosure or disposal.

bcl:text: the tribunal may remove or obscure personal information or replace personal information with anonymous identifiers.

bcl:text.in:desc: [publication of tribunal orders and other information]
bcl:text.#text: publication under section 85 , or

bcl:text.in:desc: [application of Freedom of Information and Protection of Privacy Act]
bcl:text.#text: otherwise providing or making accessible information or records referred to in section 90  or other tribunal information or records,

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Tribunal members and staff obligation of confidentiality
bcl:text: Except in the performance of their duties under this Act,
must not disclose to any person confidential information obtained in the discharge of those duties.

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a tribunal officer,
a person acting on behalf of or under the direction of a tribunal officer, or
a person engaged or retained to provide facilitated settlement

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: General rule: tribunal may not be required to testify or produce evidence

bcl:text.in:desc: [tribunal members and staff obligations of confidentiality]
bcl:text.#text: The persons referred to in section 87 (a) to (c)  must not be required to testify or produce evidence in any proceeding, other than a criminal proceeding, about information or records obtained in the discharge of their duties under this Act.
Despite subsection (1), the tribunal may produce to the court the record of the part of a tribunal proceeding that is the subject of an application for judicial review under the .

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Confidentiality of online and facilitated settlement information

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to this section, a person must not disclose or be compelled to disclose the following in a court proceeding or other legally binding process:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: any information or record provided by one party to another, and any communication made by one party to another, in the course of using the online dispute resolution services or facilitated settlement services of the tribunal;
any information obtained or record prepared by a party specifically for the purpose of resolving the dispute through dispute resolution services referred to in paragraph (a).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (1) does not apply

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the parties to the dispute consent to the disclosure,
in a criminal proceeding, or
in relation to a communication that threatens bodily harm.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Nothing in this section prevents a party from introducing into evidence in any proceeding information or records produced in the course of the dispute resolution services referred to in subsection (1) (a) that are otherwise producible or compellable in those proceedings.

bcl:marginalnote.in:doc: Freedom of Information and Protection of Privacy Act

bcl:link.in:doc: Freedom of Information and Protection of Privacy Act

bcl:text.in:desc: [powers of commissioner in conducting investigations, audits or inquiries]
bcl:text.#text: The , other than section 44 (1) (b), (2), (2.1) and (3) , does not apply to any of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: information and records in the custody or under the control of the tribunal that were obtained or created in the course of

bcl:text.in:desc: [asking the tribunal to resolve a claim]
bcl:text.#text: receiving and dealing with requests for tribunal resolution under section 4 , or

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: online dispute resolution services or facilitated settlement services of the tribunal;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the collection of personal information about an individual, without consent or from a source other than the individual, as part of the processes under sections 4 and 7;
access from outside Canada by way of electronic communication tools provided by the tribunal;

bcl:text.in:desc: [tribunal member and staff obligations of confidentiality]
bcl:text.#text: records kept by a person referred to in section 87 (a) to (c)  in providing online dispute resolution services or facilitated settlement services;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a personal note, communication or draft decision of a person referred to in section 87 (a) to (c) in relation to the resolution of a dispute;
information obtained, including evidence received, by the tribunal or a tribunal officer in a tribunal proceeding;
an electronic recording of a tribunal hearing or a transcription of a tribunal hearing;
an order of the tribunal, a final decision of the tribunal, formal written reasons for a final decision or a record of such reasons, to which public access is provided by the tribunal.

bcl:link.in:doc: Freedom of Information and Protection of Privacy Act

bcl:text.#text: Subsection (1) does not apply to personal information, as defined in the , that has been in existence for 100 or more years or to other information that has been in existence for 50 or more years.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Tribunal may be clustered with other tribunals

bcl:text.#text: Part 3  of the  applies to the tribunal.

bcl:marginalnote.#text: General offence provision of  does not apply

bcl:text.#text: Section 5  of the  does not apply to a contravention of this Act or regulations under this Act.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Offence for providing false or misleading information

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who provides false or misleading evidence or other information in a tribunal proceeding commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine of $10 000 or imprisonment for term not longer than 6 months, or both.

A person is not guilty of an offence under this section if the person establishes that, at the time the information was provided, the person did not know that it was false or misleading and exercised reasonable care and diligence in providing the information.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Power to make regulations

bcl:text.#text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations referred to in section 41 of the .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Without limiting subsection (1), the Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: respecting any matter for which the tribunal may make rules, including prescribing rules of practice and procedure for the tribunal;
repealing or amending a rule made by the tribunal;

bcl:text.in:desc: [time limit — determination of extent of responsibility for accident]
bcl:text.#text: prescribing an event and the number of days in relation to the event for the purposes of section 13.5 ;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: [Repealed 2022-6-10.]

bcl:text.in:desc: [claims within jurisdiction of tribunal for tribunal small claims]
bcl:text.#text: establishing a monetary amount as the maximum tribunal small claim amount for the purposes of section 118 (1) ;
establishing a monetary amount as the tribunal limit amount for the purposes of section 132 ;

bcl:text.in:desc: [claims within jurisdiction of tribunal for accident claims]
bcl:text.#text: respecting claims referred to in section 133 (1) (a) and (d) , including respecting any matters required to be proven and the onus of proof with respect to any matters required to be proven;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: prescribing insurers for the purposes of section 133 (1) (d);
prescribing fees that are to be paid under this Act for services provided or anything done by the tribunal;
respecting any other matter for which regulations are contemplated by this Act.

bcl:text.#text: Section 60 (1) (a), (b) and (g) to (i) and (2)  of the  applies to the tribunal.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Regulations of the Lieutenant Governor in Council under this Act may be different for different classes of claim categories, disputes, claims, issues, parties, events, insurers and circumstances, as established by the regulations.
In addition to the authority under subsection (3), regulations of the Lieutenant Governor in Council in relation to

bcl:text.#text: strata property claims may be different for different classes, as established by regulation, of strata lots and strata corporations, as defined in section 1 (1) of the ,
cooperative association claims may be different for different classes, as established by regulation, of associations, as defined in section 1 (1) of the , and
society claims may be different for different classes, as established by regulation, of societies, as defined in section 1 of the .

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Restricted authority of tribunal
bcl:section.bcl:text: The tribunal does not have jurisdiction over any of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a constitutional question;
a claim in a class of claims prescribed by regulation as being excluded from the jurisdiction of the tribunal.

bcl:marginalnote.#text: Limited jurisdiction and discretion to decline jurisdiction to apply the

bcl:text.in:desc: [limited jurisdiction and discretion to decline jurisdiction to apply the Human Rights Code]
bcl:text.#text: For the purposes of this Act, section 46.2  of the  applies to the tribunal.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Exclusive jurisdiction of tribunal — privative clause

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If, under section 1 (3), the tribunal has exclusive jurisdiction in respect of a claim category, or a class of claims in a claim category, the tribunal has exclusive jurisdiction to inquire into, hear and determine all those matters and questions of fact, law and discretion arising under this Act or required to be determined by the tribunal under this Act, and to make any order permitted by this Act to be made, in respect of the claim category or the class of claims in the claim category.

bcl:text.#text: A decision of the tribunal made in a claim in respect of which the tribunal has exclusive jurisdiction is final and binding on the parties, except the decision may be judicially reviewed in accordance with Part 5.1 .

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Specialized expertise of tribunal

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If, under section 1 (4), the tribunal is to be considered to have specialized expertise in respect of a claim category, or a class of claims in a claim category, the tribunal is to be considered to have specialized expertise to inquire into, hear and determine all those matters and questions of fact, law and discretion arising under this Act or required to be determined by the tribunal under this Act, and to make any order permitted by this Act to be made, in respect of the claim category or the class of claims in the claim category.

bcl:text.#text: A decision of the tribunal made in a claim in respect of which the tribunal is to be considered to have specialized expertise is final and binding on the parties, except the decision may be judicially reviewed in accordance with Part 5.1 .

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Jurisdiction provided for in another enactment
bcl:section.bcl:text: If another enactment gives the tribunal jurisdiction in relation to a claim, the provisions of this Act are subject to that enactment.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Claims within jurisdiction of tribunal for tribunal small claims

bcl:text.#text: Except as otherwise provided in section 113  or in this Division, the tribunal has jurisdiction to resolve a claim for relief in the nature of one or more of the following, if the amount of the claim is less than or equal to an amount, in respect of the , prescribed by regulation as the maximum tribunal small claim amount:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: debt or damages;
recovery of personal property;
specific performance of an agreement relating to personal property or services;
relief from opposing claims to personal property.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An initiating party may adjust the initiating party's claim to fit within the maximum tribunal small claim amount prescribed under subsection (1).

bcl:text.#text: The maximum tribunal small claim amount prescribed under subsection (1) may not exceed the amount prescribed by the Lieutenant Governor in Council under section 3  of the .

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Claims beyond jurisdiction of tribunal for tribunal small claims
bcl:section.bcl:text: The tribunal does not have jurisdiction under this Division in a claim

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: for libel, slander or malicious prosecution, or

bcl:text.#text: despite section 9 , for or against the government.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Meaning of words and expressions in Division — strata property claims

bcl:text.#text: In this Division, words and expressions have the same meaning as in the  or a regulation under that Act.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Claims within jurisdiction of tribunal for strata property claims

bcl:text.#text: Except as otherwise provided in section 113  or in this Division, the tribunal has jurisdiction over a claim, in respect of the , concerning one or more of the following:
the interpretation or application of the  or a regulation, bylaw or rule under that Act;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the common property or common assets of a strata corporation;
the use or enjoyment of a strata lot;

bcl:text.#text: money owing, including money owing as a fine, under the  or a regulation, bylaw or rule under that Act;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an action or threatened action by a strata corporation, including the council, in relation to an owner or tenant;
a decision of a strata corporation, including the council, in relation to an owner or tenant;
the exercise of voting rights by a person who holds 50% or more of the votes, including proxies, at an annual or special general meeting.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of this Act, the tribunal is to be considered to have specialized expertise in respect of claims within the jurisdiction of the tribunal under this Division.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Claims beyond jurisdiction of tribunal for strata property claims

bcl:text.#text: The tribunal does not have jurisdiction in relation to a claim that may be dealt with, by the Supreme Court, under any of the following provisions of the :
section 33 ;
section 52 ;
section 58 ;

bcl:text.in:desc: [removal of claim of lien after purchase from owner developer]
bcl:text.#text: section 89 ;
section 90 ;

bcl:text.in:desc: [forced sale of owner's strata lot to collect money owing]
bcl:text.#text: section 117 ;

bcl:text.in:desc: [court orders if strata corporation decides not to repair or replace damaged property]
bcl:text.#text: section 160 ;

bcl:text.in:desc: [court order when special levy resolution receives more than 1/2 but less than 3/4 of votes]
bcl:text.#text: section 173 (2) ;
section 174 ;
section 208 ;

bcl:text.in:desc: [leasehold landlord's remedies on leasehold tenant's default]
bcl:text.#text: section 209 ;
the following provisions of Part 13 :
section 226 (1) (c) and (d) ;

bcl:text.in:desc: [amendment of declaration to extend time for election]
bcl:text.#text: section 232 ;

bcl:text.in:desc: [other amendments respecting Phased Strata Plan Declaration]
bcl:text.#text: section 233 ;

bcl:text.in:desc: [orders if owner developer elects not to proceed with next phase]
bcl:text.#text: section 235 ;

bcl:text.in:desc: [order to compel completion of a phase]
bcl:text.#text: section 236 ;

bcl:text.in:desc: [order for amendment of Schedule of Unit Entitlement]
bcl:text.#text: section 246 ;

bcl:text.in:desc: [Cancellation of Strata Plan and Winding Up of Strata Corporation]
bcl:text.#text: the following provisions of Part 16 :
section 272 ;
